revised_title: Canary Parental Responses to Nestling Signals of Need
tldr: This study investigates how canary parents respond to nestling signals of need, particularly the interaction of chick size and hunger levels on chick proximity to the parent and food distribution within the brood. The results show that although chick size has the strongest effect on proximity, hunger level also plays a role. When chick position is controlled, parents respond to other cues, such as posturing and calling behaviors, when allocating food.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Animal Behavior
